column2: > on average wealthy give away a smaller fraction of income than poor! I agree this is very weird, and seems like the sort of thing that absolutely could be improved by promoting certain kinds of non-capitalist motivations, and am very interested in this problem :)
Agree, I think you make a very valuable point here.

And here's me trying to encourage development of schemes to encourage financial capital owners to convert their capital into social capital https://twitter.com/vitalikbuterin/status/939489302869770240?lang=en …
FWIW https://www.ft.com/content/b09d004e-4197-11e8-803a-295c97e6fd0b … is arguably an example of me doing the former. That said, I appreciate the point.

Though even with NYT, I'd argue that even though I think NYT is very high quality, that doesn't imply its model is replicable. Very many "news sites" really are just the equivalent of Reddit commenters wearing suits.
Right, I was targeting the 573 Steemit clones more so than NYT and co.
I think the point of controversy here is, working for social capital is absolutely sufficient for a *part time job/hobby*, but obviously can't work for *full time*.

Think of programming tutorials as an archetypal example. People write them to show off how they're a smart software engineer, and we have plenty of those for every language under the sun. It seems to me like this category is very broad.
I don't think "wealthy" is the right emphasis. I've seen plenty of things written by people with no expectation of direct financial return when those people just have various kinds of regular jobs.
Content is not produced "for [region X]". It's produced for the world, because that's how the internet works. The rich regions pay and benefit, the poor regions pay a little but still benefit.
Oh I'm not just interested in the US.
I've already expressed my disagreement with that article:https://twitter.com/VitalikButerin/status/992068638982238208 …
Doesn't content written for money have the exact same problem?
And content written for money didn't?
Very much look forward to ideas in this regard!

That said, there are plenty of "low-visibility" tasks for which it's hard to earn social capital, *and* which are boring, but which are important. Those areas are probably the ones where improving monetization can add the *most* marginal value.
Agree fully!

Agree this is worth exploring; @ glenweyl's recent book brought it up. That said, there is the critique that all of these services are only making something like $10-20 per user per year, so there's no *that* much gold that can be mined.

I think that's conflating content creation and curation somewhat. I actually agree curation is important, and strongly support R&D of better social technologies for curation. And I would even say that monetary incentives are *underutilized* on the curation side.
"Also it is a little contradictory to your introduction where you offer advertising for ICOs" FYI that is a joke. Hence "noreply@buterin.com". As in, *I DON'T EVEN LOOK AT THAT INBOX*.
Happy that they exist, but it's very very hard for voluntary donations to add up to a full time job's worth of income.

Social media approval is as good as your curator set. Right now having good curators is definitely not a default, but I think it could get there over time. And trusting traditional info authorities as curators is deeply problematic in its own ways.

> who ensures the quality of the content Today, likes, retweets, various curated lists. In the future, hopefully better mechanisms will appear. > Or what are the incentives of writing well researched articles As I said, social capital. I'm not asserting a need for altruism.
Kept them maximally low, did odd programming jobs.

So an implication here is that content creation of the kind I'm talking about should not be a person's sole full-time job. Which is possibly for the best; cf Heinlein's "specialization is for insects".

But what if every monetization strategy either (i) earns you $4.75 even for an article that gets thousands of views, or (ii) inherently requires polluting or restricting the content in some way that heavily decreases its value?

Yes, but the desire for social capital can incentivize positive-sum activity. Technically money is zero-sum too, but it's easy to see how that doesn't imply that the entire economy is a waste of time.
Free open source software.
No, but a social capital card can be immensely useful in getting jobs.

I wrote hundreds of articles for bitcoin magazine for far below minimum wage, if not free, before starting ethereum. So if you want to talk about my own experience as an example, IMO it perfectly confirms that shooting for social capital is a totally fine incentive.

Part of me feels that interest in content monetization may be misguided. Maybe we should just accept that certain kinds of work (writing articles, indie FOSS dev, etc) should be done for social capital, and not money. IMO this was one of the virtues of 2000s-era internet culture.
